title: Hollywood icon Diane Keaton dies aged 79
text:
L﻿egendary actress Diane Keaton has died at the age of 79.

There are no further details at this time and her family has requested privacy, a spokesperson told People﻿ magazine, which first reported the news.

Keaton was the kind of actor who helped make films iconic and timeless, from her "La-dee-da, la-dee-da" phrasing as Annie Hall , bedecked in that necktie, bowler hat, vest and khakis, to her heartbreaking turn as Kay Adams, the woman unfortunate enough to join the Corleone family in The Godfather .

Diane Keaton was one of Hollywood's most beloved figures. (Getty)

Her star-making performances in the 1970s, many of which were in Woody Allen films, were not a flash in the pan either, and she would continue to charm new generations for decades thanks in part to a longstanding collaboration with filmmaker Nancy Meyers.

Keaton won her first Oscar for Annie Hall and would go on to be nominated three more times, for Reds , Marvin's Room and Something's Gotta Give .

In her very Keaton way, upon accepting her Oscar in 1978 she laughed and said, "This is something."

READ MORE: ﻿ Whistleblower claims alarming safety fails at embattled childcare chain

Keaton with her Oscar in 1978 after her performance in Annie Hall. (AP)

Bette Midler, who starred with Keaton in The First Wives Club , paid tribute in a post on Instagram: "﻿The brilliant, beautiful, extraordinary Diane Keaton has died. I cannot tell you how unbearably sad this makes me.

"She was hilarious, a complete original, and completely without guile, or any of the competitiveness one would have expected from such a star. What you saw was who she was…oh, la, lala!"

Octavia Spencer remembered Keaton as "[not] just an actress: she was a force. a woman who showed us that being yourself is the most powerful thing you can be".

"﻿From Annie Hall to Something's Gotta Give , she made every role unforgettable. But beyond the screen, she brought joy, laughter, and style that was all her own. Thank you, Diane, for reminding us that authenticity never goes out of fashion," Spencer's tribute read.

Keaton was born Diane Hall in January 1946 in Los Angeles, though her family was not part of the film industry she would find herself in.

Her mother was a homemaker and photographer, and her father was in real estate and civil engineering.

Keaton made her film debut in the 1970 romantic comedy Lovers and Other Strangers , but her big breakthrough would come a few years later when she was cast in Francis Ford Coppola's The Godfather , which won best picture and become one of the most beloved films of all time.

And yet even she hesitated to return for the sequel, though after reading the script she decided otherwise.

READ MORE: Major changes to how Aussies travel in Europe

Keaton in 2015. (Richard Shotwell/Invision/AP)

The 1970s were an incredibly fruitful time for Keaton thanks in part to her ongoing collaboration with Allen in both comedic and dramatic roles.

She appeared in Sleeper , Love and Death , Interiors , Manhattan , Manhattan Murder Mystery and the film version of Play it Again, Sam.

Allen and the late Marshall Brickman gave Keaton one of her most iconic roles in Annie Hall , the infectious woman from Chippewa Falls whom Allen's Alvy Singer cannot get over.

The film is considered one of the great romantic comedies of all time, with Keaton's eccentric, self-deprecating Annie at its heart.

- Reported with Associated Press﻿

title: Betting on using frequent flyer points for a holiday? Think again
text:
Steve Hui is known as the "Points Whisperer", one of the Australia's foremost authorities on maximising return from frequent flyer points, and he has a warning for Aussies.

There's a huge change coming ﻿for the rewards landscape, and it's not looking good.

Hui predicts that ﻿the Reserve Bank of Australia's (RBA) proposed reforms banning surcharges on eftpos, Mastercard and Visa cards could slash the number of points everyday Aussies earn with each purchase.

Steve Hui warned Aussies there are big changes coming to the way we earn frequent flyer points. (Instagram/@iflyflat)

So if you're a Qantas Frequent Flyer, Virgin Velocity Frequent Flyer, or other points collector who earns through card purchases, you might soon be a lot worse off.

"Your ability to earn points will drop in a number of areas," Hui, founder of points travel advisory iFLYflat, told 9news.com.au.

"A lot of credit cards will have to change their reward system because the revenue won't be there to pay for these rewards at the current level."

For example, credit cards that currently offer one frequent flyer point ﻿per dollar spent may drop to one point per $2 spent, or more.

In short, ﻿earning frequent flyer points will get more expensive.

Hui said the RBA's proposed ﻿surcharge and interchange reforms will significantly impact how Aussies earn points and how many they can earn in a single transaction.

"I believe it will change the whole rewards landscape in Australia, and probably be the biggest change in 15 years," he said.

"What we don't know is when the changes are going to be implemented."

But as it becomes harder to earn points and the number of points required to access rewards﻿ keeps going up, is it even worth it for everyday Aussies to be part of frequent flyer loyalty programs anymore?

A growing number of consumers don't seem to think so.﻿

New research from Finder revealed 57 per cent of Aussies – equivalent to more than 12 million people – no longer see the value in Qantas or Virgin's programs.

Only one in three think Qantas Frequent Flyer points are worth the chase, and just one in four believe Virgin Velocity points are worth it.

These attitudes should come as no surprise, given that Velocity recently slashed the number of points non-Velocity credit card holders earned per dollar while Qantas﻿ hiked up the points needed to redeem fares.

Hui understands why some Aussies have been turned off frequent flyer programs but said they still have plenty of value for those who play it smart.

﻿"It really all comes down to people working out what's the cost versus benefit of the points," he said.

"If benefit exceeds cost, then it's always worthwhile."﻿

The cost is the fee paid to collect the points, like annual credit card fees or surcharges, while benefit can be rewards like flights and seat upgrades.

READ MORE: Paedophile allowed to have photo of his victims at his bedside as he died

"If benefit exceeds cost, then it's always worthwhile."﻿ (Getty)

But making the most of your points isn't as simple as accruing a bunch and spending them on anything.

The biggest mistake Aussies make with frequent flyer programs is not knowing how many points they actually need to get the rewards they want.

﻿Hui said the best tactic is to decide where you want to go and what class of fare you want, find out how many points it costs, and work backwards.

Work out which retailers offer the points you're collecting and prioritise them whenever you can, from the supermarket (Qantas Points with Everyday Rewards at Woolworths) to the petrol station (Velocity Points at 7-Eleven stores.

Hui also encourages everyday consumers to pick one program and stick with it to hit their points goals and earn rewards faster.

Spreading points around usually only works for business travellers who fly constantly, who can learn how to optimise their points with a membership program Hui is set to launch next week.

READ MORE: Man arrested over fire that destroyed 6000 LA homes

Hui is the founder and chief executive of iFLYflat, which claims to be Australia's top points travel experts. (Instagram/@iflyflat)

If you're tossing up ﻿which frequent flyer program to focus on, Hui's favourites in 2025 have been Virgin, Qatar and Cathay Pacific.

Qantas didn't make the cut, but don't jump ship if you're already collecting Qantas points.

Instead, Hui said to focus on accruing as many points as possible in the program you're already with before the RBA's proposed surcharge reforms kick in and potentially slash your earning power.

"Make hay when the sun shines because the system's always changing and if you wait, then you may miss out."

title: Final 'game changing' piece of Metronet rail project opening in Perth's south-east
text:
The final piece of the Western Australian government's flagship Metronet project, the long-awaited Byford rail extension in Perth's south-east, will open tomorrow, half a billion dollars over budget.

Community events are planned today to celebrate the milestone, which extends the existing Armadale line 8 kilometres south to a new ground-level station in Byford.

The line will allow commuters to get from the new Byford train station, which features 400 parking bays, to Perth in 46 minutes.

Premier Roger Cook and Transport Minister Rita Saffioti will launch the new rail line. (ABC News: Cason Ho)

The Shire of Serpentine-Jarrahdale President Rob Coles said it was a significant development for the rapidly growing population.

"About 75 per cent of our residents leave the shire each day and go to work, and on average they travel about 23 kilometres one way," he said.

"So this really is a game changer for our residents to be able to access employment.

"We are currently the fastest growing local government in WA and number three in Australia, the growth is rapid and things like the train station and other infrastructure really is so important."

WA's new Metronet trains unveiled Photo shows New white train with green stripes being built at a railcar manufacturing facility. The WA government's signature project is facing cost blowouts, delays and a slow uptake in train patronage and an economist calls it risky.

The Byford Rail Extension was originally expected to cost $797 million, but has risen to $1.33 billion.

Businesses celebrate opening

The grand opening has been eagerly awaited by some residents and business owners in Byford, who have had to cope with a large section of the Armadale line being closed for almost two years.

Hair salon owner Sharlene Sandiana was looking forward to better transport links and potentially more customers.

Sharlene Sandiana says the new station could help her business. (ABC News: Lily Kristanto)

"Transport around here has been pretty bad for the last few years, so it'll be great," she said.

"We're already quite busy here as it is, so hopefully it'll get a little bit busier; a bit of extra passing traffic, a bit of good exposure."

It will be 46 minutes from Byford to Perth. (ABC News: Lily Kristanto)

Impact of roadworks

Byford pharmacy assistant Bridget Ellement said roadworks related to the project had impacted some businesses.

"It affected the road access and people just found it a bit harder, so they were like, 'Oh well, I'll just go to a different pharmacy or go to a different area,'" she said.

"I know the bakery next door … struggled a little bit.

"They were closing a bit earlier, which was a bit disappointing to see, but we're definitely excited to see [the train line] open and see more people."

Bridget Ellement says the new rail line will be beneficial for elderly residents. (ABC News: Lily Kristanto)

Ms Ellement also said the new rail line would make it easier for elderly residents to access health services in Armadale.

"We have had people come in and ask, 'Can you call me a taxi so I can go into Armadale?', so it definitely has been an accessibility thing," she said

Seven level train crossings have been removed and two new road-over-rail bridges have been built as part of the project, with 8 kilometres of new walking and cycling paths created.

Perth's first east-west rail connection opens Photo shows Roger Cook wears a blue suit as he smiles while standing on a train The Thornlie-Cockburn link and adjacent rail elevation in Perth's south-east is part of WA Labor's flagship infrastructure project Metronet.

Since November 2023, thousands of commuters in Perth's south-east faced disruptions to their travel, with the closure of sections of the Armadale/Thornlie line as part of the project.

The Armadale line between Cannington and Perth stations reopened in June with the new Thornlie-Cockburn line, while the remainder between Beckenham and Armadale stations will reopen tomorrow, along with the new Byford Station.

Have something to share with the ABC's WA newsroom? Photo shows Perth City and Claisebrook Cove Whether it's an image, video, story, or tip-off, you can send it to the ABC's West Australian newsroom here.

title: We have a lot of spare bedrooms — but boarders' rights are unclear
text:
When the Portland Memorial Bowling Club put out a call for housing for its newest chef, regular customer Ellen Linke did not hesitate.

She took Anoop Thapliyal into her home in February 2024 with no formal agreement, no house rules, just a simple premise of trust.

"I thought, well, if he's good enough to be employed by them, I think I can offer him a place," she said.

Ellen Linke (right) has taken up three boarding arrangements, including with Renu Thapliyal and her husband. (Supplied: Anoop Thapliyal)

The split-second decision gave Mr Thapliyal an immediate base after his journey from Abu Dhabi to country Victoria.

Living with a stranger without a lease did not faze him.

"The very first day when I talked to her [Ms Linke], I just realised that she's a really nice lady, so I was depending on that thing only," he said.

Anoop Thapliyal was conscious of being a considerate boarder. (Supplied: Anoop Thapliyal)

"If they [boarders] are lucky, they will find … people like Ellen Linke, but I don't know if everyone is lucky."

Mr Thapliyal's wife Renu eventually joined him at Ms Linke's house. By October, the pair had found their own rental.

Make me a match

Beris Campbell wished boarding was more common.

Ms Campbell helped create Australia and New Zealand's peak body for homesharing, and said the arrangement could benefit both parties — especially when organised through a paid service.

"Being a matchmaker is a very skilled and difficult, challenging situation because you are trying to bring people … to live together," she said.

" For God's sake, that's the hardest thing that we do is all trying to get on with each other. "

Jacinta Duffy said her father could have lived longer if boarding had delayed his move to residential aged care.

She now runs a business vetting and supporting boarding arrangements, particularly in regional areas.

Jacinta Duffy had a positive experience boarding as a student with an elderly relative. (Supplied: Life Shared)

"I'm swamped with people who want to be home companions," she said.

"The need is so much there for people who are seeking housing full stop, let alone affordable housing and housing that's well-located.

" I think it'd be a huge positive solution to the housing crisis that we can act on now … we're not waiting for properties to be built. "

A solution to the housing crisis?

Australia has 13 million spare bedrooms, according to census analysis by Queensland University of Technology's Lyndall Bryant.

The university's Housing Security Research Group lead said boarding was "a real grey area" that needed a clearer regulatory framework and further tax exemptions to encourage older Australians to host.

"There's no silver bullet for the housing crisis, but every little piece will help," Dr Bryant said.

"So even if 1 per cent of those …13 million bedrooms were released to the market, then that's 130,000 extra bedrooms.

"That would make a significant difference."

Lyndall Bryant says it is inefficient for there to be one spare bedroom for every two people. (Supplied: QUT)

The federal government aims to build an average of 240,000 homes each year until 2029, but current completion rates are falling short.

Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) governor Michele Bullock is also locked into spare bedrooms, telling a house economics committee last month the housing crisis was not just about supply, but "declining household size".

Property analyst Cotality released research in August showing most houses have at least three bedrooms, but most households contain fewer than three people.

The company's Australian head of research Eliza Owen said this could be addressed by incentivising downsizing: abolishing stamp duty, implementing land tax and including the family home in the pension asset test.

Eliza Owen says it is more important to incentivise appropriately sized housing. (Supplied: Cotality)

Slippery entitlements

Boarding is not a solution without risks.

Tenants Victoria lawyer Ben Cording said ambiguity arose in situations not covered by the Victorian Residential Tenancies Act.

The legislation spelt out obligations for renters and landlords, but excluded private arrangements such as boarding.

"The key defining difference for those two things is what's called exclusive possession," he said.

"There's a lot of complicated factors that sort of fall into deciding the difference, and this often is not spelt out … really clearly in the legislation, it comes through decisions from the court."

Ben Cording says expectations, conduct, shared spaces and locks can play a role in reaching the legal threshold of exclusive possession. (Supplied: Tenants Victoria)

Mr Cording said he would also like to see housing laws amended to protect boarders.

"There's got to be a balance that we want people to be hospitable … but we also want to absolutely make sure that we're not exposing people who have no other alternative to housing to be exploited," he said.

The Victorian Minister for Housing did not respond to the ABC's request for comment.

title: Move over muster dogs — there's a new cat in town
text:
A ginger cat perched on his owner's lap, tearing across Queensland's mulga country by motorbike is enough to make anyone do a double-take.

Raised alongside working dogs, Mango the muster cat isn't your average feline.

Spot the odd one out. (Supplied: Beck Smith)

The whiskered four-legged influencer of the outback comes complete with his own Facebook page, loyal followers and even fan mail.

"When I go to the mailbox, there's packages for Mango. There's ladies who even bake him his own treats. He gets tins of salmon, cat clothes, little shoes," owner Beck Smith said.

A pair of crocs Mango was sent by a fan. (ABC Western Qld: Hannah Walsh)

"Everyone loves Mango."

Ms Smith said Mango's rise to fame happened almost by accident after she sent videos to friends of her and Mango surveying flood damage around their property earlier this year.

Mango is one year old and has a sassy personality. (ABC Western Qld: Hannah Walsh)

"All they got out of it was, 'Hang on, is that a cat on the bike with you?'" Ms Smith said.

"He comes on the bike with the dogs, he gets tied on the back of the car with the dogs, he's been mustering, he helps down the yard drafting and working weaners," Ms Smith said with a chuckle.

It's the duality of the outback; finding humour in harsh times.

Loading...

"Having him there takes away the harshness of talking about the devastation … a lovely little fluffy cat with personality, it draws people in," Ms Smith said.

"People are laughing at him and his antics, but then they are also seeing what we're going through as well."

Mango and mental health

Ms Smith lives on and runs a 52,600-hectare station solo near Stonehenge, a tiny town about 90 minutes from Longreach in central-west Queensland.

Beck Smith runs Evengy station near Stonehenge in central-west Queensland. (ABC Western Qld: Hannah Walsh)

During destructive flooding earlier this year, Ms Smith estimated about 70 per cent of her property went under water.

It's been a domino effect since, not being able to muster or sell cattle, and the bills piling up.

"I try not to think about that dollar figure too much, because if you do, it does become very overwhelming," she said.

"The days are never long enough, and you never get half the things you want done each day."

Beck Smith does not know the full extent of her stock losses yet. (ABC Western Qld: Hannah Walsh)

Rebuilding fences and purchasing the materials to do so has put Ms Smith back at least $100,000.

And it's money that must be spent up-front before she can be reimbursed through government grants.

"That's the issue … most people don't have that money sitting there ready to go," she said.

Posting videos to social media of Mango being "one of the dogs" helps Ms Smith talk about life on the land after disaster.

Mango enjoys riding in the quad bike. (Supplied: Beck Smith)

She said mental health was still a taboo topic in the bush.

"I used to be very embarrassed by my mental health journey and then I just got to the point where it's part of my healing process to speak about it, and if one person can relate and will put their hand up for help, then I've paid it forward," she said.

" People on the land don't like to be seen as having any weaknesses because you've got to be tough, you've got to be able to handle everything that life throws at you. "

Which, she said, was even more apparent if you were a woman.

"There's a lot more women working in the agriculture industry now … but it's still very much a man's playground," she said.

Beck Smith says she does not have time to be lonely, especially with all her animals. (ABC Western Qld: Hannah Walsh)

"Whatever a man does, you have to do it twice as hard and tough than what they do.

" I'm expected to bake the cake and be a bush mechanic too. "

But Ms Smith said as she got older, it worried her less and life on the land was second nature.

Deep in the Mulga, with Mango by her side, she continues rebuilding after ruin.

Mango on the two wheeler. (ABC Western Qld: Hannah Walsh)

"It's just one of those things you've got to keep putting one foot in front of the other."

title: Live: Rain is falling at Bathurst as lead drivers jump into their Supercars
text:
Todd Hazelwood has made the perfect start from the front, after his lead driver, Brodie Kostecki, secured pole position.

Drivers have not bee afraid to get their elbows out as the fight for position in the early laps of the Bathurst 1000.

All teams are looking up to the skies, with rain almost certain to fall during the famous race.

Follow all the action from the great race in our live blog.

Key Events IT'S RAINING IN BATHURST! 9 minutes ago WE'RE GO AT BATHURST 1 hours ago Bathurst map 1 hours ago Show all key events 31/161: Bit of bumping as the rain sends nerves scattering S By Simon Smale (Fox Sports) Randle just hit Le Brocq in a move for 10th place on the final turn. Tom Randle may have to give that place back. Car #14 is back on the race track M By Michael Doyle is car 14 out for good? - Flermit Hello Flermit. Thanks for joining us on the Bathurst 1000 live blog. It is great news for Brad Jones Racing and the team for the #14 car. It stalled off the line, and had come into the pits twice with an issue. While all other cars were flying around the mountain, the team for #14 were completing a complete overhaul of the car's transaxle. Car #14, with drivers Bryce Fullwood/Brad Vaughan, is now racing again. Now, they are more than 20 laps behind the leaders, so don't start believing in any miracles. However, if a car completes 121 laps, it will be classified as a finisher. It is a great effort from the team to get that car back on track and a chance of being classified today. 30/161: Aaron Cameron has made big contact at the cutting! S By Simon Smale (Fox Sports) Getting a bit slippery up there, lads? 29/161: Here's how the top five looks after the first hour of racing S By Simon Smale #88 - Broc Feeney/Jamie Whincup (Red Bull Ampol Chevrolet) #38 - Brodie Kostecki/Todd Hazelwood (Shell V-Power Ford) #99 - Cooper Murray/Jobe Stewart (Chiko Chevrolet) #2 - Ryan Wood/Jayden Ojeda (Mobil 1 Truck Assist Ford) #1 - Will Brown/Scott Pye (Red Bull Ampol Chevrolet) IT'S RAINING IN BATHURST! S By Simon Smale Spots of rain on the camera. Spots of rain on the windscreen. Things might be about to get even more interesting... It's certainly not heavy yet, though. Cam Waters: I'd prefer to be in the car if it's raining S By Simon Smale Cam Waters is one of only three lead drivers to not be in the car at the moment. He says it's OK to have Mark Winterbottom in the car for now though. "Yeah, obviously there is rain on its way. I probably prefer to be in the car if it rains, but if it does rain now, it's not the end of the world," he says on Fox Sport. "He's got a lot of experience. We're going OK." Speaking of rain... 25/161: Ryan Wood and Mark Winterbottom are going at it S By Simon Smale Awesome battle up on top of Mount Panorama as Ryan Wood is all over the back of Mark Winterbottom through the cutting. Winterbottom shows all his skill to keep Wood at bay, but he can't stop him from running up the inside of the Chase and that's some superb driving from this pair to stay away from each other. Great driving. Meanwhile, everyone has stopped once and we'll just wait to see how things settle out. 24/161: Bit of damage to car #26 S By Simon Smale (Fox Sports) Just a little bit of a bruise on the back of the Penrite #26 car driven by Kai Allen/Dale Wood. 23/161: Main drivers coming in, but not all of them S By Simon Smale Fox Sports is reporting that most of the lead drivers will be coming into the car during this pit stop window. But there are some notable exceptions. Brodie Kostecki, Cam Waters and Chad Mostert are all sitting and enjoying what they're seeing so far. They don't have the helmets on so they will be unlikely to get into the car at this stop. Is that risky with the rain imminent? 21/161: Big moment for Hazlewood S By Simon Smale Todd Hazlewood with a big slide at McPhillinay Park. He is nearly 2 seconds clear at the front of the race. But that was a big moment. A bit of dampness up on the mountain? We haven't heard it's raining yet... 20/161: When do we start thinking about wet weather tyres? S By Simon Smale Thomas Randle is into the #55 car, with James Moffat coming out. Slick tyres on there. If they have to come in again very soon, that will be a disappointment for that team. When will the rain hit? S By Simon Smale Soon. Very, very soon. There is some debate as to exactly when they will start getting wet though. Team 18 have been telling their drivers the rain will come down in 17 minutes. But in one of the other teams, it's going to be 44 minutes.

Don't go anywhere. 20/161 The top six have a big advantage over the field M By Michael Doyle We have achieved 10 per cent race distance, and there is a clear gap between the top six and the rest of the field. The currently top six are: #38 - Brodie Kostecki/Todd Hazelwood (Shell V-Power Ford) #99 - Cooper Murray/Jobe Stewart (Chiko Chevrolet) #6 - Cam Waters/Mark Winterbottom (Monster Energy Ford) #88 - Broc Feeney/Jamie Whincup (Red Bull Ampol Chevrolet) #2 - Ryan Wood/Jayden Ojeda (Mobil 1 Truck Assist Ford) #25 - Chaz Mostert/Fabian Coulthard (Mobil 1 Optus Ford) This group are separated by seven seconds. There is an eight-second gap between #25 - Chaz Mostert/Fabian Coulthard in sixth, and Will Brown/Scott Pye (#1 Red Bull Ampol Chevrolet) in seventh. The field will bunch up with a safety car, but with green flag racing, there seems to be a distinct gulf between the top six and the rest. We still have the majority of the field with co-drivers in the car. This can all change with the lead drivers. 19/161: Some movements up and down the field S By Simon Smale Some errors up and down the field. Cooper Murray is up into second as Mark Winterbottom just gets a little bit out of shape - nothing too much. Garth Tander goes wide and Craig Lowndes comes through for 14th place. #38 - Brodie Kostecki/Todd Hazelwood (Shell V-Power Ford) #99 - Cooper Murray/Jobe Stewart (Chiko Chevrolet) #6 - Cam Waters/Mark Winterbottom (Monster Energy Ford) #88 - Broc Feeney/Jamie Whincup (Red Bull Ampol Chevrolet) #2 - Ryan Wood/Jayden Ojeda (Mobil 1 Truck Assist Ford) #25 - Chaz Mostert/Fabian Coulthard (Mobil 1 Optus Ford) 17/161: Scott Pye makes a great move S By Simon Smale (Fox Sports) Lovely stuff from Scott Pye, who moves up into seventh place. Cam McLeod is the man who gave him a lot of room. There was another pit as well, James Courtney comes into the pits and swaps with Jack Perkins. There's a bit of stuff dangling off the back of the car, perhaps just race tape. (Fox Sports) 16/161: First pit stop S By Simon Smale Nick Percat is into the #10 car, an early change there as Tim Slade gets out after a short first stint. 15/161: Whincup is flying S By Simon Smale Jamie Whincup has just set the fastest lap of the race, 2.07.7. We're still about 10 laps from the first fuel pitstops. #38 - Brodie Kostecki/Todd Hazelwood (Shell V-Power Ford) #6 - Cam Waters/Mark Winterbottom (Monster Energy Ford) #99 - Cooper Murray/Jobe Stewart (Chiko Chevrolet) #88 - Broc Feeney/Jamie Whincup (Red Bull Ampol Chevrolet) #2 - Ryan Wood/Jayden Ojeda (Mobil 1 Truck Assist Ford) #25 - Chaz Mostert/Fabian Coulthard (Mobil 1 Optus Ford) 14/161: Contact between Scott Pye and Harry Jones S By Simon Smale (Fox Sports) Scott Pye has just made contact on his way through past Harry Jones. Jones was a bit stunted by that out of the final corner and is under pressure from Lee Holdsworth in the battle for 13th. RAIN DROPS ON THE MOUNTAIN! S By Simon Smale Cooper Murray has just reported some rain drops. Not much more than that, but it's coming and that fact is just raising the anticipation levels across the circuit. There are even a couple of umbrellas up in the stands at Skyline. On suspicion? Or are they reacting to something up there? 12/161: Jamie Whincup into fourth S By Simon Smale Another lovely move from Jamie Whincup. He overtakes Jayden Ojeda. At the front, the lap gap is getting smaller, down from two seconds to 1.1 to Cooper Murray, and both the lead drivers are pushing hard too, a lock up from each heading off the mountain. #38 - Brodie Kostecki/Todd Hazelwood (Shell V-Power Ford) #6 - Cam Waters/Mark Winterbottom (Monster Energy Ford) #99 - Cooper Murray/Jobe Stewart (Chiko Chevrolet) #88 - Broc Feeney/Jamie Whincup (Red Bull Ampol Chevrolet) #2 - Ryan Wood/Jayden Ojeda (Mobil 1 Truck Assist Ford) #25 - Chaz Mostert/Fabian Coulthard (Mobil 1 Optus Ford) Show more posts

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

title: Once parched and bare, these paddocks are now flourishing again
text:
Looking at Abby Miller's fat, new season lambs standing amid belly-high, neon-green pasture today, it is hard to believe the same paddock was a brown, barren dust plain just a few months ago.

For the past two years, the Naracoorte farmer and accountant has been battling drought and dramatically low livestock commodity price slumps, which saw sheep make as little as $2 per head at saleyards.

Like many farmers throughout South Australia, those in the south-east where Mrs Miller farms, have been in a desperate position.

At the height of her community's call for action, she penned a letter to SA Premier Peter Malinauskas, expressing the burden of hardship being borne by farmers — locally, around the state and across the border into western Victoria.

Young lambs on a drought-affected paddock at Richie and Abby Miller's farm near Naracoorte. (Supplied: Rosemary Miller)

Lambs graze on the same paddock at Richie and Abby Miller's farm near Naracoorte. (Supplied: Rosemary Miller)

Mrs Miller's words would underpin expanded, emergency drought support for South Australian farmers.

Today, the Miller farm — and many others in the region — paint a more positive picture.

The lambs born on bare, brown paddocks just a few months ago are now grazing on lush, fresh feed.

Crops sown with hopes and prayers now stand tall in swathes of yellow and green.

"It's good to walk down the main street or take kids to local sport and see people smiling again," Mrs Miller said.

"I think the South East is feeling optimistic.

"After these early spring rains, people can now say 'let's keep going' which is quite a turnaround, coming off the back of two very tough years."

Tough times build tough people

While some South Australian regions remain on a knife-edge, Mrs Miller said some farmers on the Limestone Coast had the opportunity to claw back financial losses, with some districts recording up to 2 inches of rain in the first week of October.

"To know we can feed our lambs and grow our crops to their full potential — it's positive and so many farmers here are smiling and saying there's opportunity there," she said.

The outlook in the Upper South East is also much improved.

Richie Miller and his son feed sheep during the 2024-25 drought in Naracoorte, SA. (Supplied: Abby Miller)

Michael Hunt farms at Cannawigara near Bordertown, where the season also got off to a memorably difficult start.

"We started planting some barley and some canola and then we stopped because it was dead, dry, dusty and depressing," he said.

"We had a team meeting and decided to just keep going. We were full of self-doubt … but eventually it rained."

A grazing property in the Penola district has been revived with recent rains. (ABC South East SA: Liz Rymill)

That rain helped improve the season, with Mr Hunt now on track to have an average harvest year.

"I don't think I've ever seen it turn around like that," Mr Hunt said.

Conditions 'much better'

Lower South East farmer Trevor Rayson had around 40 millimetres of rain on his property in Hatherleigh, 15 kilometres north-west of Millicent, in the first week of October.

With the improvement of conditions, Mr Rayson said he was on track for an average harvest year, much better than he expected three months ago.

Trevor Rayson says another big rain would be needed in the next month to help crops finish successfully. (ABC South East SA: Elsie Adamo)

"We're so much better off than we were … from where we've come from, that's really good," he said.

" It doesn't rain grass, it rains potential. "

While the crops on his farm are looking healthy, Mr Rayson doesn't need to travel far for the outlook to change.

"Even just 10 or 15 kilometres down the road and the crops don't look as bright," he said.

"We might just be in a very lucky patch."

Those patchy results are a common occurrence across the South East according to senior agronomist with Delta Ag in Keith, Scott Hutchings.

Scott Hutchings says there has been enough rain for most pastures to get some decent yields for livestock. (ABC South East SA: Elsie Adamo)

"There is some unevenness in some of the cropping and pasture and that can be who's had individual rainfall events," he said.

Mr Hutchings is expecting crops and pastures south of Keith to have average to slightly above average yields this season, but for those farmers further north it is a different story.

"In my area, my variation from north to south is the most I've seen for a long, long time just because of lower rainfall as we move north," he said.

Lessons remain after rains arrive

Farmers are often not big on celebrating the wins publicly, aware others could be in much tougher situations, but Mr Hunt wanted to provide a bit of hope.

Canola flowers have brightened up the South East in the last month. (ABC South East SA: Elsie Adamo)

"I'm just aware of all of those that are having a tough year, keep the chin up," he said.

"I was feeling very low in May, but once things started turning around you realise that it's not forever.

" Sometimes you've got to be thankful for what you've got. "

Mrs Miller echoes this sentiment.

"I sometimes feel bad for feeling good because I know that there's still a lot of farmers across the state who don't know what happens next," she said.

"Farming is a small community — you're in it together, and I think reaching out to friends in regions where it's tough is still very important.

"Even just a phone call or a message over social media matters."

title: From racism to romance: Gregory Porter's songs hit hard
text:
Gregory Porter's voice is velvet and thunder.

That duality — smooth yet commanding — perfectly reflects the emotional depth and genre-spanning versatility that defines his career.

Porter's musical versatility is one of his greatest strengths. While rooted in jazz, he's equally at home in gospel, blues, and soul.

Hear Gregory Porter's full interview on The Music Show Photo shows a Black man smiles at the camera, wearing a suit and a hat that covers his ears and throat, swimming pool in the background Gregory Porter is at home in gospel, blues, soul, and R&B. But the foundation of it all, he tells Andrew Ford, is jazz.

His captivating live performances have delighted audiences from Glastonbury's main stage to intimate jazz clubs. He was the voice of Disclosure's dancefloor anthem Holding On and he recently released a characteristically cool Christmas album.

Porter sees each recording as a reflection of a moment in time.

"Any given record is just a snapshot of what an artist is on that particular day," Porter tells Andrew Ford on Radio National's The Music Show.

"If I make a record, if I take the same content and same songs and record it three months down the line, it's gonna sound quite a bit different based on what I'm feeling, based on how I feel like expressing a particular song."

Loading Instagram content

Porter quickly embraced the value of versatility, giving him a rich palette of musical expression.

"Knowing that I have these things within my wheelhouse — gospel, blues, soul and the foundation of it all being jazz — I use all of the devices and come to the feeling that I like the best, based on what I feel that day.

"I don't feel like I'm tied to expressing in one way because I feel like all this music belongs together.

" The musicians that played on Saturday night were often the musicians who were on the side of the pulpit playing the music in church on Sunday morning. "

Extracting beauty from darkness

This fluidity of style also extends to the themes Porter explores in his music.

He is a deft hand with a love song: the tender Hey Laura, the determined Consequence Of Love, the devotional Heaven are just a few textbook examples of how to capture the intoxication of love in song with requisite class.

Gregory Porter performs as part of Queen Elizabeth II's Platinum Jubilee celebrations at Buckingham Palace in June 2022. (Reuters/Chris Jackson)

And he has just as much impact, if not more, when singing songs that take on less comfortable subjects.

"It ceases to become a performance, it then carries on a bit of a cause," he says of instilling deeper meaning into a song. "It just gives a song a little bit more nutrition, in a way."

The song Mister Holland from Porter's 2020 album All Rise is a perfect example. The song's protagonist goes to a young woman's door and, when her father answers, they chat calmly.

"By the way, Mister Holland, I like the way you make no trouble of my skin," Porter sings in the song's second verse.

While the song was based on a true story, the reality of the situation wasn't as friendly as the song laid it out to be.

Loading Instagram content

"Mister Holland is an example of me, in a way, rewriting a really negative experience that I had," Porter says.

"A girl that I liked, I went to her house to go for a soda or something like this. Anyway, I went to the door, and it was a super negative experience. I was told to get away from the door.

"Basically, Mister Holland is rewriting the story of something that happened to me when I was a teenager.

" In the song, I'm treated with respect, and I'm treated just like any regular normal teenager and there was no problem with my skin colour. There was no questioning. "

The song's warmth and conviviality mask the ugliness of the real-life experience it's based on.

"I found as a songwriter and as a performer early on that when I write from personal experience, from something that I really care about, something that moves me, that my delivery is more authentic and it's a bit more true."

This wasn't just Porter rewriting his own history: he spun gold from a harrowing experience. He took the ugliest human behaviour and turned it into something truly beautiful.

He says he had no choice.

"If it's something that weighs heavy on my heart or something that I think about that may be happening to other people, the melody and the poetry will come to me. It can take some work afterwards. But the feeling and the melody will kind of just rise up out of me."

The music and message live inside him, waiting to be released. Porter releases these emotions to heal, and to help others do the same.

"I would love if I made a song like that and it sells a bunch of copies," he says.

"But if the soulful message that's embedded within gets out to the people and has some effect, that's more valuable than anything."

Love and optimism are worth fighting for

Another classic example of how Porter's thoughtful music serves, and one even more universal, is Porter's brilliant 2013 track No Love Dying.

The song serves as a poignant reality check: in a world where love is often dismissed, Porter stands firm in its defence.

Loading Instagram content

Porter knows that we don't need to bow to that way of thinking, and No Love Dying is a quiet but formidable protest.

"I wrote that song with the idea of writing a song in the defence of optimism about love," Porter says.

He's comfortable being optimistic about life and love, because he knows it's important.

Love doesn't always win. If we want to benefit from its power, we need to let it in. It may not always be easy and we may have been conditioned otherwise, but it's there.

"It's not blind optimism," he says of his most positive songs. "It's optimism in the face of difficulty.

"This is the type of optimism that I think my mother had. The type of optimism that the civil rights workers had.

"It's the type of optimism that I think, sometimes, political people have. On either side of any issue. They believe in what it is they're working for, and they believe that it's possible through work.

Gregory Porter has won two Grammy Awards for Best Jazz Vocal Album (Reuters/Lucy Nicholson)

"Yes, I'm encouraged about love and about people and about peace. But not in the idea that it exists, in the idea that we have to work for it. I don't believe that there is perfect equality and perfect conditions of love and of peace. These are things that we have to work for.

"I always put that in the song when I write about optimism about love. I'll often state the opposition to the cause of peace and love and grace."

And he quotes:

"The death of love is everywhere. But I won't let it be. There will be no love dying here for me."

Gregory Porter's Australian tour kicks off at Hobart's Odeon Theatre on Wednesday night before hitting Sydney, Brisbane, Melbourne and Perth.

You can hear Gregory Porter's full interview on The Music Show, available anytime on the ABC Listen app.

title: 'Administrative error' leads to council's unregistered vehicle fleet
text:
Tasmania's West Coast Council has blamed an "administrative error" for a week-long lapse in the registration for its entire fleet of vehicles.

Registration for the vehicles, including passenger cars, trucks and heavy machinery, expired on September 30, and the bill was not paid for renewal until October 7.

During that time multiple vehicles were used on public roads, illegally and without valid insurance.

Queenstown is the principal town in Tasmania's West Coast Council. (ABC News: Maren Preuss)

Lapsed rego 'not a good look', GM admits

Acting general manager Bill Hutcheson confirmed the oversight, and said it was the result of a miscommunication between departments at the council.

He said the alarm was raised on Wednesday afternoon when a staff member using a council car "realised that it actually wasn't registered".

"So therefore, that vehicle was taken off the road straight away," he said.

The West Coast Council is based in Queenstown. (ABC News: Maren Preuss)

He said he acted as soon as the issue was identified, and the council paid the $45,000 bill to re-register the vehicles within 30 minutes.

"If it had have taken longer, we would have had all the vehicles straight off the road," he said.

Mr Hutcheson said it was unclear how many of the council's fleet had been driven during the week they were unregistered, and said much of the heavy machinery would not have entered a public road.

"Some of them might be, just for instance, they might be used at our waste disposal sites," he said.

"So, they're not actually out on the road all the time. But we still need to get them registered."

He agreed the situation was "very concerning" as vehicles need to be registered for insurance to be valid.

"If there had have been an accident, then our insurance wouldn't have covered us," he said.

Scott Riley has taken responsibility for the oversight, as West Coast Council's general manager. (ABC News: Maren Preuss)

Scott Riley, the council's general manager, said he was unaware of the situation prior to being asked as he was on leave this week but agreed it was concerning.

"That is not a good look at all," he said.

"It's a significant concern, given that we're supposed to be law abiding citizens."

Mr Riley said he was not typically involved in managing the council's vehicle fleet, but as the general manager he accepted responsibility.

Union concerned, minister referring matter on

Sam Batchelor, Tasmanian coordinator for the Australian Services Union, said she intended to meet with Local Government Minister Kerry Vincent.

"The ASU was notified by members that council vehicles were being unknowingly driven unregistered by workers," she said.

"While we have received confirmation that the matter has been rectified, this points to one of many ongoing issues in our councils."

Minister Vincent said he had "no jurisdiction over operational matters of councils".

However, as the minister for transport, he said he referred the matter to the Registrar of Motor Vehicles for further investigation.

Under Tasmanian law, driving unregistered vehicles can attract significant fines and further penalties for subsequent offences.

title: Healy backs Aussie batters to fire despite stuttering start to World Cup
text:
Alyssa Healy says she is not concerned by Australia's top-order frailty in its first two World Cup wins and is confident in its batting as it faces its biggest test yet against host India.

Healy's side won its opening two matches thanks to stunning rescue knocks from Ash Gardner against New Zealand and Beth Mooney against Pakistan, aided both times by some dogged assistance from the lower-order.

But with India also having faced its own batting trials and tribulations, coming off a shock defeat against South Africa on Thursday, Healy expects both the two favourites' big guns to start delivering at Sunday's sell-out.

Beth Mooney bailed Australia out with a stellar knock against Pakistan. (Getty Images: Matthew Lewis/ICC)

"We're allowed to lose games of cricket and we're allowed to be put under pressure at times, in particular in World Cups," Healy said when asked if she was concerned by Australia's form.

"You're going to be put under the pump in unfamiliar conditions, against unfamiliar sides at times.

"I really back our depth in our side and our squad, that the 11 we put out on the park are going to be able to get the job done for us.

"And we're fortunate it's been a different person every time that stuck their hand up and said, 'yep, I've got this, I can get us to a total' or 'I can take the wickets to restrict the team'. So I wouldn't say it's a worry.

"It's something we'd like to rectify. I think it's on our top order to make the bulk of the runs, and I think we can speak on that from both sides."

The hosts will doubtless agree with their star batters — Smriti Mandhana, captain Harmanpreet Kaur and Jemimah Rodrigues — all having misfired so far during the tournament.

On Thursday, they all fell cheaply, leaving it down to Richa Ghosh to pull out a big-hitting 94 at number eight, which was still not enough for India to avoid defeat thanks to an even more astonishing knock from the South Africans' Nadine de Klerk (84no).

India has endured its own batting woes at this World Cup. (AP: Anupam Nath)

Healy said India remained a major threat to Australia's World Cup crown.

"The rivalry continues to grow. I feel like India have been almost a sleeping giant in the women's game for a long period," she said.

"It's probably since the Women's Premier League that they've realised the depth they've got and they've figured out a style of play they want to want to use, especially in this format, which has been really impressive to see.

"In their home conditions, they're obviously going to play really well and be a real threat, but as we've seen throughout this World Cup so far, there's lots of teams that are pushing everybody.

"So I wouldn't probably say there's one team that's our main threat. We know we're going to have to work hard in every fixture to get our result and that's the way a World Cup should be."

AAP

title: Starcevich 'good to go' at West Coast despite concussion concerns
text:
West Coast recruit Brandon Starcevich says he has no worries about his concussion history after completing his trade from the Brisbane Lions to the Eagles.

Starcevich, who missed almost two months of football this year due to concussion, sat out the end of the grand final after a heavy collision with Geelong's Ollie Dempsey, sparking concern about his future in the game.

Starcevich has suffered several consussions during his career (AAP Image/Jono Searle)

But the dual-premiership defender says he didn't suffer a concussion in that incident.

"A cautious approach with it all [sitting out the end of the grand final]," Starcevich told ABC Perth's Summer Sportstalk.

"No need to take a risk, especially with me I think was most of it."

The 26-year-old, who moved from to the Eagles in a three-way trade, has consulted several experts to ensure he can keep playing in the AFL.

"With all the feedback I've gotten around my situation, I'm fairly positive that I'm fine and good to go," he said.

"All the professionals I spoke to when I had that bit of time off at the start of the year sort of ticked me off and said I was fine.

"I've had no lingering issues or anything, so I'm pretty positive about the whole thing."

From premiers to wooden spooners

Starcevich's decision to return to Perth was sparked by conversations had at the end of the 2024 season, as he entered the last year of his Brisbane contract.

Starcevich played 132 games for the Lions since debuting in 2018. (AAP Image/Darren England)

"I thought I'd like to explore it a little bit and the idea of potentially coming back to Perth and playing, being back among your friends and family, was very appealing," he said.

"The appeal of the young talent that is at the Eagles and starting that climb back up the ladder is definitely a new challenge, sort of a fresh adventure."

The East Perth product conceded he'd miss Brisbane after giving up the chance to go for a third-straight premiership with the club, but was always heading home.

"I made my mind up and there was never anything that was going to change it," he said of his decision to move.

"It's better to go out winning it. I think losing it would probably feel a little bit more empty, but it's nice I got to go out on a high."

Have something to share with the ABC's WA newsroom? Photo shows Perth City and Claisebrook Cove Whether it's an image, video, story, or tip-off, you can send it to the ABC's West Australian newsroom here.

Loading...

The ABC of SPORT Sports content to make you think... or allow you not to. A newsletter delivered each Saturday.

title: Buyers priced out of market as developer finds sunset clause loophole
text:
On their honeymoon in Queensland more than half a decade ago, Fatin Jebeili and Maher Santina fell in love with the Gold Coast, resolving to leave Sydney behind and move there one day if they could.

So, when the opportunity came up to put down a deposit on an off-the-plan, four-bedroom townhouse for $595,000 in 2022, it seemed like that dream was about to become a reality.

Three years later, the couple and their two daughters are instead living a nightmare.

Their townhouse is yet to be finished, and the developer of Urbana Residences is trying to cancel their contract and return their deposit on the grounds the sunset date expired in August.

Ms Jebeili and Mr Santina hoped they'd be living on the Gold Coast by now, but they're still renting in Sydney. (ABC News: Glenn Mullane)

After years of delays, the move has devastated the couple, who said they had been priced out of an exploding property market.

"Even if we go more remote in Sydney or in [the] Gold Coast or anywhere ... it's going to be a struggle," Mr Santina said.

" We're just kind of desperate. "

Parts of Urbana are complete, or almost completed. (ABC News: Glenn Mullane)

Stage set for a fight

Sunset clauses are provisions in contracts that allow a developer, or a buyer, to terminate a contract if the build isn't complete and settled before a specified date.

Loading

But Urbana buyers allege developer Cadmium Land FW2 Pty Ltd has deliberately dragged its feet on construction, so it could exploit the sunset clause and resell the properties at what would now be market value.

The Brisbane developer did not respond to repeated requests for comment but has denied the allegations in correspondence seen by the ABC.

Ms Jebeili and Mr Santina, who are among those who hope to launch legal action against the company, said the delays and emotional toll of the past few years had been enormous.

Preparations made years ago to move — as they had expected their home to be ready in 2023 — now seem in vain.

Ms Jebeili had enrolled in a university course in Queensland, Mr Santina told his work he'd be moving, and they enrolled their daughters in daycare in a different state.

"It's been the worst feeling I have ever had to go through," Ms Jebeili said.

"Not knowing where to enrol the [girls] when it comes to childcare or taking care of planning for their future education."

The family has struggled with the uncertainty of not knowing where to enrol their daughters in daycare and planning for the future. (ABC News: Glenn Mullane)

They had imagined their second-born Layana, who is now two-and-a-half, would be living in her own room in Queensland by now.

Instead, they're still renting a too-small place in Sydney.

"They just kept giving us hope bit by bit ... and then we wait, and then we're halfway there," Mr Santina said.

" We decided just to be patient. "

That patience is now wearing thin.

Samuel Amey lodged a petition with the Queensland government, calling for it to bring sunset clause legislation in line with other states. (ABC News: Glenn Mullane)

In his apartment on the Gold Coast, Samuel Amey has also run out of patience.

Mr Amey and his now-wife Anabel Djuric signed a contract in December 2021 for a three-bedroom, $649,000 townhouse in stage three of Urbana Residences.

He said he was told it was meant to be completed in 12 months.

It's still not ready.

They too had dreams of having a bigger place than their current two-bedroom walk-up apartment so they could hopefully start a family.

But the delays to the build have meant they have put those dreams on hold for now.

Mr Amey says he and his wife have had to put off starting a family because of the delays. (ABC News: Glenn Mullane)

Just like in Mr Santina and Ms Jebeili's case, Mr Amey's been issued with a contract termination because his sunset date has also expired.

His lawyers requested an extension, which he said was declined, leaving the newlyweds in limbo.

"It feels like such a waste ... we've put so much time and energy into this property that we were hoping to start a new life in," he explained.

"We've almost been held hostage and effectively been priced out of the market now."

Urbana Residences' buyers are in the process of launching legal action against the developer. (ABC News: Glenn Mullane)

Developer denies allegations

In a letter addressed to Duke Myrteza, who is one of the lawyers acting for the Urbana buyers, lawyers acting for the developer strongly denied the claims of deliberate delays.

"The Seller strongly denies that ... the construction of the development was delayed for any reason attributable to 'neglect' or any lack of diligence on its part," the response, dated July of this year, read.

Australian Law Partners' Duke Myrteza is working with Urbana Residences' buyers. (ABC News: Mark Leonardi)

In the correspondence, Cadmium Land FW2 Pty Ltd's lawyers also rejected claims of failing to pay sub-contractors or breaching any contractual obligation to the buyers.

"The Seller denies that it is in substantial breach of the Contract or that it has engaged in misleading and deceptive conduct," the letter stated.

It also said the buyers' allegations were lacking "evidence" and had been made in "broad and sweeping terms".

Mr Myrteza, along with another lawyer, is preparing legal action on behalf of about 20 Urbana buyers. (ABC News: Lottie Twyford)

Mr Myrteza, solicitor at Australian Law Partners, said about 20 buyers were in the process of launching legal action against the developer.

He explained the case rested on a claim the developer had breached its obligations in the contracts they later tried to cancel.

"There were significant delays in the construction of the development and completion of the townhouses," he claimed.

"As well as actions such as completing later stages in the development before completing earlier stages — in other words, manipulating the construction schedule to suit the developer to allow time to pass the sunset date.

"At the end of the day, all we need to establish is a breach on the part of the developer in terms of its obligations under the contract."

Some parts of Urbana are still under construction. (ABC News: Glenn Mullane)

A push to reform laws

As well as the legal action, Mr Amey also wants to see legislative changes in Queensland to tighten rules around developers using sunset clauses to terminate a contract.

Queensland off-the-plan land buyers given greater protections Photo shows A man in a light blue polo and glasses looks at the camera looking despondent. Andrew and his wife bought a block of land to build their forever home. Months after signing the contract, the couple were told their contract would be terminated because the financier of the development wanted the blocks to sell for a higher price.

In particular, he wants to see Queensland bring its laws more in line with those in New South Wales, where apartment, unit and house buyers are afforded the same protections as land buyers.

He recently lodged a petition with the government, which garnered more than 1,700 signatures, urging a review of sunset clauses in off-the-plan property contracts.

The state government has announced a review of the legislation, which was last reformed in 2023 under the former Labor government.

The 2023 changes mean developers now need the written consent of buyers, or a Supreme Court order, to terminate an off-the-plan land contract using a sunset clause.

But the changes only apply to off-the-plan land sales, rather than off-the-plan property sales, leaving the Urbana buyers without that protection.

Attorney-General Deb Frecklington announced in September the government would review sunset clause legislation. (ABC News: Cameron Lang)

A government spokesperson said buying a property was one of the "biggest financial commitments" many Queenslanders would ever make.

"[The government] appreciates the huge disappointment when an off-the-plan contract is terminated through a sunset clause," a statement read.

"The Crisafulli government is undertaking an in-depth review of Labor’s sunset clause amendments and has invited community, industry and other stakeholders to share their views and experiences."

Mr Santina and Ms Jebeili wanted to move to Queensland for a slower pace of life. (ABC News: Glenn Mullane)

While there's an acknowledgement any change may come too late for this group, Ms Jebeili is adamant that won't stop them from trying.

"I hope there is light at the end of the tunnel, even if it didn't work out for us," she said.

"At least ... I hope that some laws can get reviewed and help someone else."

title: When 4yo Zyan was in pain, a blue knitted octopus kept him calm
text:
On the way to the emergency department earlier this year, Canberra mum Guinevere Laurenco worried about how her son Zyan would cope with the noisy, unfamiliar environment.

Headed straight from the GP, they did not have the chance to pack any clothes or toys for the four-year-old.

"We didn't have anything for him," Ms Laurenco said.

Zyan had been limping for a couple of days and complaining of leg pain. Suspecting it was transient synovitis, which causes hip pain and inflammation, the GP recommended they go to Canberra Hospital.

Zyan still treasures his 'blue squiddy' gift. (Supplied: Guinevere Lourenco)

It was an overwhelming situation for the four-year-old.

"He was in pain, he didn't know what was going on, different people [were] talking to us, [there was] a lot of crying.

" But then the front desk lady gave him a toy. From that moment he was holding it tight. "

It was a knitted octopus, later dubbed 'blue squiddy' by Zyan.

"It was soft and small and colourful … hand-sized for him," Ms Laurenco said.

"He would hold it one hand, close to his chest … It was really a comfort for him throughout his stay."

Zyan's 'blue squiddy' is one of more than 6,000 handmade gifts made every year by a team of volunteers based in Canberra.

Their mission is to give comfort to patients, all while bringing a community together.

Even those who aren't the most adept knitters are welcome to join the charity. (ABC News: Yasmine Wright Gittins )

'It's not just a toy'

The charity Good Omen Goodeze (GOG) has been creating 'comfort goodies' for almost eight years.



Since its inception by founder Mary Liondi-Barlow, the group has grown to include more than 265 volunteers.

The volunteers knit, crochet and package an assortment of gifts — blankets, teddy bears, beanies, small fidget toys.

Then the goods are delivered to hospitals and health care centres across the ACT.

Patients, young and old, may be handed a gift to bring them comfort during their stay.

When Julie Samuels joined GOG, she hadn't crocheted in many years but relearnt with the help of other volunteers. (ABC News: Yasmine Wright Gittins)

They make so many gifts that committee member Julie Samuels said they were constantly calling for yarn donations on social media.

Ms Samuels said they were trying to show the potential of their gifts to help patients.

"It's not just a toy; it's a therapeutic comfort," she said.

Hospital and doctor visits can be overstimulating, and medical procedures can increase anxiety among patients, particularly young children.

The use of therapeutic toys in healthcare is long recognised, with most hospitals providing patients with play areas and sensory activities.

"One of the results of our quality assessment is that when they use the toys, the kids', the adults', and this is unexpected, the staffs' stress levels reduced ... and facilitated them being able to then treat the children quickly," Ms Samuels said.

She said the goodies could also have potentially long-term benefits with patients able to take them home.

"They become a safety item."

The hum of voices and clacking of knitting needles sets the scene for the weekly catch-up. (ABC News: Yasmine Wright Gittins)

Reaching the socially isolated

From conversations in the knitting aisle at Spotlight, to community outreach programs, the charity draws in volunteers from across Canberra.

Ms Samuels said it was part of GOG's mission to bring volunteers together in a way that transcended language, age and cultural barriers.

"It's a place for Canberrans to come that's safe, respectful. They can volunteer, they can meet new friends, enjoy new connections," she said.

"There are a lot of people who are socially isolated in Canberra. It is an epidemic."

Critically, the catch-ups are coupled with a sense of purpose.

Deidre McCurdy says she "gets withdrawals" if she misses one of the catch-ups. (ABC News: Yasmine Wright Gittins )

"For those that have been that have been socially isolated, it gives them a sense of pride, helps the self-esteem, helps self-confidence," Ms Samuels said.

It is something to which Deidre McCurdy can attest.

Ms McCurdy moved from Queensland just two and a half years ago with her son and daughter-in-law. While Canberra is not her original home, she found her place at GOG.

"I really had no friends here whatsoever," she said.

When she was invited to join the group, that changed.

"I absolutely love it here, met so many nice people, it's a lovely group to join," she said.

"I'm just so glad I found them because it has kept my sanity in check … I get withdrawals, I think, if I don't come here each week."

The 86-year-old has been knitting since she was eight and finds joy in making goodies like her knitted bears.

"It's so pleasing to think that you've done something that a child or an adult really likes," she said.

" I can keep knitting if this is the reaction that we are getting from people in hospital. "

Handmade chickens, dolls and creatures are some of the most popular gifts. (ABC News: Yasmine Wright Gittins)

A good, lasting memory

Zyan was back to his normal four-year-old self after a couple of days in hospital.

But he still treasures his 'blue squiddy' gift.

Ms Laurenco said when moving house recently, he was quick to make sure 'blue squiddy' was not lost in the move.

" He knows and he remembers — he still remembers getting this from the 'big hospital'. "

She hopes that it will make future hospital visits easier and leave Zyan with positive feelings about the hospital.

"It was a good memory amongst a situation that is not easy," she said.

"We greatly appreciate it as a family and on his behalf."

title: Two aunties' idea for year 12 celebration thrives after almost two decades
text:
Attending the Koori Formal is becoming a proud tradition for Indigenous students on the New South Wales Mid North Coast such as Shaylor Thompson.

The Dunghutti teen has always lived in Kempsey and was one of 30 First Nations students from across four Macleay Valley high schools who recently graduated from year 12.

Macleay Valley high school students gathered at Melville High School in Kempsey for the annual Koori Formal. (ABC Mid North Coast: Sophia McCaughan)

"It's really good to see everyone else succeed and finish year 12," she said.

" Not a lot of kids get that opportunity, especially around … Kempsey. "

The formal was an occasion to cherish.

"It's been really good and exciting, it's great to see all the families here watching their babies get to graduate," Shaylor said.

Graduation rates

Using the most recent census data, the National Indigenous Australians Agency found non-Indigenous Australians aged between 20 and 24 we 1.3 times more likely to have completed year 12 or an equivalent level of study.

The situation was something local elders Aunty Jackie Welsh and Aunty Natalie Smith have long been determined to address.

Jackie Welsh and Natalie Smith came together nearly 20 years ago to found the Koori Formal. (ABC Mid North Coast: Sophia McCaughan)

About 17 years ago the aunties, who worked as Aboriginal Education Officers at the time, hatched an idea to hold a special dinner for First Nations graduates in a bid to motivate others to stick with their high school education.

"It gave us an opportunity for everyone to come together and celebrate, without all the frictions that may be present in the wider community," Aunty Natalie said.

They took their idea to the principals of Melville and Kempsey high schools, which paid for the first Koori Formal.

First Nations students celebrate reaching year 12 and graduating. (ABC Mid North Coast: Sophia McCaughan)

The event has since expanded to celebrate all Indigenous graduates across Macleay Valley high schools, with more than 200 tickets sold this year.

For Aunty Jackie, making sure the event is accessible for all to attend is crucial.

"The Koori Formal is just about the kids and their parents, so the parents can congratulate their kids and be proud of their kids for reaching that level," she said.

"A lot of parents and their kids don't go to the main formal … it could be the cost or that they have limited numbers that can go."

Overcoming challenges

Isiah Heuston, who is a Gumbaynggirr teenager living on Dunghutti country, was among those at this year's Koori Formal hosted at Melville High School.

Isiah Heuston has plans to go to university after graduating. (ABC Mid North Coast: Sophia McCaughan)

He was the 2025 vice-captain of Melville High and says the Koori Formal was a big motivator that helped him complete his final years of school.

"There definitely have been a few challenges, ups and downs throughout high school but I've overcome them, whether it be teacher support or through Mum and Dad," he said.

" Dad said no matter what I do in the HSC or whatever it may be, he's proud of me, I got here in the end. "

Melville High School principal Andrew Ryder said the Koori Formal was a celebration of a major educational milestone for First Nations students.

Andrew Ryder says he is immensely proud of all the First Nations students graduating. (Supplied: Kim Ambrose)

"It's fantastic, it really is a great achievement for all the schools to get their students to the HSC and to graduate high school," he said.

In the nearly two decades the Koori Formal has been running, it has never missed a year, even during the coronavirus pandemic when it had to be held online.

The Koori Formal in Kempsey has run every year for nearly two decades. (Supplied: Kim Ambrose)

Former student and 2024 graduate Zailen Campbell-Cook Flanders attended the formal this year with his sister.

"She's done well to follow in my footsteps, and finish school, I'm proud of her," Zailen said.

"I reckon a Koori Formal should be done for all Indigenous students around New South Wales or even Australia," he said.

Zailen Campbell-Cook Flanders attended this year's Koori Formal with his sister. (ABC Mid North Coast: Sophia McCaughan)

The state's Education Department says, from 2022 to 2024, the number of First Nations students enrolled in year 12 on the Mid North Coast grew by 7.9 per cent.

A similar event was held on the state's south coast, where Catholic and independent high schools gathered on Dharwal lands for their fourth annual Deadly Grad.

More than 200 people attended the Koori Formal earlier this year at Melville High School. (ABC Mid North Coast: Sophia McCaughan)

Koori Formal founders Aunty Jackie and Aunty Natalie hope their legacy continues well into the future.

"Whoever takes over from me and Natalie in the future, I'd like to see that they will continue and encourage the parents and kids to be part of it," Aunty Jackie said.

"The foundations are already built there, I'd like to see somebody continue it."

title: Storer makes Aussie cycling history but is no match for Pogačar at Il Lombardia
text:
Michael Storer has made cycling history by becoming only the second Australian rider in 120 years to make the podium at the Tour of Lombardy monument classic, but he was still a distant sideshow to one final amazing Tadej Pogačar solo triumph of 2025.

Perth rider Storer battled magnificently over the final climb for third place, but couldn't live with the "big two" Pogačar and Olympic champion Remco Evenepoel as they embarked on their latest one-sided duel in Italy on Saturday.

After soloing away from his Belgian rival at the World and European road race championships over the previous two weekends, Pogačar again proved unstoppable as he made his decisive kick 36 kilometres from home on the final, bruising Passo di Ganda climb.

In his final hurrah of what he feels is his best season yet, four-time Tour de France champ Pogačar won by one minute 48 seconds, equalling the great Italian Fausto Coppi's five victories in Il Lombardia while also becoming the first man ever to win the race five years in succession.

It was the crowning glory to another astounding season in which the Slovenian master won the Tour, the world and European titles, three Monuments — Lombardy, Liège-Bastogne-Liège and Ronde van Vlaanderen — the Critérium du Dauphiné and UAE tours, as well as the La Flèche Wallonne and Strade Bianche classics.

Together with his second place finish at Paris-Roubaix and third at Milan-SanRemo, Pogačar is the first rider in history to finish on the podium of all five Monuments in a single season.

It was his 20th win altogether in 2025, so Tudor Pro's Storer could probably feel it was a considerable achievement just to have finished only 3:14 behind Pogačar, who took victory after 5 hours 45 minutes and 53 seconds in the saddle.

Tadej Pogacar added yet another win to his 2025 record. (Getty Images: Dario Belingheri)

Tudor could also look back on his best season yet after a terrific ride over the 241km course from Como to Bergamo.

The 28-year-old had tried to go with Evenepoel after they had both been left for dead by the Slovenian, but he was distanced by the Belgian superstar over the final 10km and battled home for the third spot, 25 seconds clear of American Quinn Simmons.

It represented another breakthrough ride for Storer, who becomes the only Australian apart from Phil Anderson in 1986 to make the podium at the Tour of Lombardy since its inception in 1905.

It was also Storer's maiden Monument podium in a year when he also earned his first stage victory at Paris-Nice, followed by both a stage win and the overall triumph in Tour of the Alps.

He also finished in the top-10 in the Giro d'Italia and recently won the prestigious Memorial Pantani race.

There was a strong Australian showing all round, with Jay Vine still managing to finish ninth while working for his UAE Team Emirates leader Pogačar, Ben O'Connor 18th and Michael Matthews 21st.

AAP/ABC

title: ‘I haven’t laughed so hard in a long while’: The latest Fringe reviews are here
text:
Sheppard’s performance is loaded with hilarious subversion, packing in camp and toilet humour, outrageous physical comedy and pop-cultural lampoon, alongside cheerful critique of existing aesthetic hierarchies. It lobs lightning bolts at every vice (and many a sacred cow) in theatrical and critical culture, and the comedic storm she whips up has a smiling eye of calm in West’s divine presence. Carly Sheppard’s performance is loaded with hilarious subversion Credit: Jacinta Keefe I haven’t laughed so hard in a long while. Anyone involved in the theatre world will marvel at how up-to-the-minute the comedy is; fans of super irreverent humour generally – South Park leaps to mind – should love this show, too. Although – like South Park – it might be too “tasteless” for some, there’s genuine liberation in satire this fearless and clever, and to me, the show’s dissection of the politics of taste is all part of its charm. ★★★★

Reviewed by Cameron Woodhead

THEATRE

Mammalian Diving Reflex | Nightwalks with Teenagers

Werribee (various locations), season ended Nightwalks with Teenagers took place in Werribee as part of Melbourne Fringe Festival Reviewing a work by Mammalian Diving Reflex is a bit like reviewing the last conversation you had. The Canada-based company makes “socially engaged participatory performance” which usually involves assembling folks who might never otherwise cross paths, providing them a structure through which to interact, and then just seeing what happens. In this case you’re invited to wander the backstreets and public gardens of Werribee for a few hours in the company of more than a dozen local teens. They’ve designed activities to explore along the way, from a dance-off and karaoke to a bunch of getting-to-know-you games, and while there’s no spectacle or showstopping moment, there are countless opportunities for real connections to be made along the way. It’s a gentle rebuke to the reductive image of troubled teens that generates headlines, and a reminder that today’s youth have much more in common with yesterday’s than we might realise.

★★★★

Reviewed by John Bailey

COMEDY

Chelsea Heaney | I Swear I’m Funny

Motley Bauhaus, until October 12 When a performer opens the show sashaying down the aisle delivering an absurd burlesque-style striptease, the assurance in the title – I Swear I’m Funny – hardly seems necessary; the audience is already laughing. Chelea Heaney performs at Motley Bauhaus until October 12. Credit: Nathan Smith Having won over the room, Chelsea Heaney sets about examining what influences have turned her into the funny woman on stage before us. A task predominantly undertaken through standup, peppered with a skit or two, a song and some physical comedy. These interludes are pitch-perfect both in musical ability and comedic timing. No surprise then that she lists musical theatre as one of the reasons she’s funny alongside family, eavesdropping and more. Heaney knows how to set up an anecdote for maximum laughter payoff, delivering punchlines and unexpected twists with theatre-kid aplomb. A nod should also go to her skilful audience interactions, which add charming touches to her stories. The show comes together as a satisfyingly energetic and charismatic whole.

★★★★

Reviewed by Lefa Singleton Norton

CIRCUS

Casey Lorae | La Folie After Dark

Gasworks Theatre, until October 11 La Folie After Dark is on at Gasworks Theatre until October 11. Credit: All The Feels Photography It begins with a warning: brace yourself for “blasphemy, BDSM and assault”. Seated in a dark, hazy room looking at a suspended hoop and chains, it’s not entirely clear what you’ve walked into. But once the first performer contorts her body, uncertainty is replaced by sheer awe. Metres in the air, she lifts and twists her body effortlessly, draping her limbs around the hoop as if she were liquid. The power of the human body is on full display, whether on a hoop, trapeze, silks or straps. Artists freefall from ceiling-height, do the splits in midair, and lift other artists by the neck with their feet. It defies belief yet appears so sultry and seamless. Though each individual act astounds, the production as a whole lacks cohesion. A baffling attempt to link two performances using a prop cup interrupts your stunned reverie. La Folie struggles to connect the dots, but it’s still testament to the breathtaking strength and seductiveness of the human form.

★★★

Reviewed by Nell Geraets

THEATRE

Dylan Murphy and Tom Henry Jones | In the Dark

Trades Hall, until October 12 Somewhere in a secret bunker, five comedians are waiting for electricity to be siphoned from a dystopian wasteland so they can start their humble radio show: the right hand of an authoritarian regime trying to calm rebellion via foley artistry, morality tales and theatricalised propaganda. Imagine an Orwellian Orson Welles, or The Hunger Games as an interwar broadcast.
